section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: Hands-on programming section focusing on Python variables, data types, and basic operations with practical exercises
learning_objectives: Create and assign variables using appropriate naming conventions
Identify and use Python's basic data types (integers, floats, strings, booleans)
Perform operations on different data types
Convert between data types as needed
Debug type-related errors in Python code

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables, assign values, and follow Python naming conventions

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create 5 variables with different valid names: one for your age as an integer, one for your name as a string, one for your height as a float, one for a boolean indicating if you like programming, and one for a list of your favorite colors. Print all variables to verify their values.

Identify which of the following variable names are invalid and explain why: 1st_place, user_name, total-value, class, _private_var, max_score, user@name. Then create valid alternatives for the invalid ones.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use integers and floats, perform arithmetic operations, and understand type differences
key_topics: Math functions from the math module

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a program that calculates the area and perimeter of a rectangle. The program should have variables for length and width, perform the calculations using appropriate operators, and print the results. Test with integer and floating-point inputs.

Create variables to store a temperature in Celsius. Convert it to Fahrenheit using the formula: F = (C Ã— 9/5) + 32. Print both temperatures with descriptive labels. Test with multiple Celsius values including negative numbers.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, modify, and format strings using various string methods
key_topics: Common string methods (upper, lower, strip, replace)

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create a string variable with your full name. Using string methods, create and print: 1) Your name in all uppercase, 2) Your name in all lowercase, 3) Your name with first letter capitalized, 4) The number of characters in your name, 5) Your initials extracted using slicing.

Create variables for a person's name, age, and favorite hobby. Use f-string formatting to create a personalized greeting message that includes all this information. The message should be properly formatted with punctuation and spacing.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use boolean values and logical operators to make decisions in code

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for two numbers and a string. Write boolean expressions to compare these values using all comparison operators. Print each expression with a description of what you're comparing.

Create variables for username, password, and is_active status. Write boolean expressions to check: 1) If username and password are not empty, 2) If username length is at least 6 characters, 3) If user is active, 4) If all conditions are met simultaneously. Print the results.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert between data types and check variable types programmatically
key_topics: Using int(), float(), str(), bool() functions
Type checking with type() and isinstance()
Converting user input strings to numbers

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables of different types (string numbers, float values, booleans). Convert each variable to all other possible types using conversion functions. Print the original type, value, converted value, and new type for each conversion.

Write a program that accepts two numbers as input (using input()), converts them to appropriate numeric types, performs addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, then displays the results. Include type checking to ensure valid numeric input.
